item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:34, topic:198221”][quote author=chrisn2323 link=topic=262873.msg2181967#msg2181967 date=1208041814]
Really? I always associated them with flight
[/quote]

GetCameraPitch and getCameraYaw seem perfectly logical in this situation because in flight the pitch and yaw are relative to the airplane’s center of mass. In this case it isn’t the camera which moves freely (although it can be modified to do so as in yakman’s hack), but the camera is grounded to some origin within the player.[/quote]the camera still moves and rotates…

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

chrisn2323:

Really? I always associated them with flight

GetCameraPitch and getCameraYaw seem perfectly logical in this situation because in flight the pitch and yaw are relative to the airplane’s center of mass. In this case it isn’t the camera which moves freely (although it can be modified to do so as in yakman’s hack), but the camera is grounded to some origin within the player.

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:32, topic:198221”]Really? I always associated them with flight

Anyway they work because when I saw “Pitch” and “Yaw” I had a pretty good guess as to what they did as opposted to minimapInt3 or even angle for that matter.[/quote]

the minimap variables are named fine.

getCompassAngle,
getCompassAngleOffset,
getMinimapScale.

we are talking about the cameraCurve X / Y or what can be called cameraAngle X / Y.
but yes, as i have previously stated, pitch and yaw are fine.

but really tbh, why does it matter if someones names differ, i could use zyxx as a method name and it not bother me,
yes it would make more sence to name it something uniform and maybe abstract. but for personal bots, aslong as you understand it, it is fine.

Read full topic

pitch, yaw and roll are standard terms used to describe any rotational movement of an object

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

chrisn2323:

I don’t really associate the moving of a camera with the moving of a airplane, but I guess if you think of the center of the airplane being the center of the gamescreen, then it works.

the clients camera holds properties similar to flight dynamics, the only rotation which has yet to be implemented is roll.

@yakman, getCameraYaw and getCameraPitch are suffice, however why not just name them getPitch and getYaw? since they are static camera values, there are no other Pitch or Yaw look-a-likes in the client

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:26, topic:198221”]agree, the word “curve” is annoyingly ambiguous and you can also get curves from quadratic and cubic equations, sin/cos are not the only way to get curves.

those arrays aren’t exactly caches of the Math.sin() Math.cos() things, the ones in the Math class use radians, so a full circle for them is 2*Pi, but for angles used in the client, a full circle is 2048 or something,

i was thinking of the names “sinCache” and “cosCache” perhaps?

am I the only person who thinks getCameraPitch() and getCameraYaw() is a good idea?[/quote]
I don’t really associate the moving of a camera with the moving of a airplane, but I guess if you think of the center of the airplane being the center of the gamescreen, then it works.

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Angle:

In geometry and trigonometry, an angle (in full, plane angle) is the figure formed by two rays sharing a common endpoint, called the vertex of the angle. The magnitude of the angle is the "amount of rotation" that separates the two rays, and can be measured by considering the length of circular arc swept out when one ray is rotated about the vertex to coincide with the other (see "Measuring angles", below). Where there is no possibility of confusion, the term "angle" is used interchangeably for both the geometric configuration itself and for its angular magnitude (which is simply a numerical quantity).

Curve:

In mathematics, the concept of a curve tries to capture the intuitive idea of a geometrical one-dimensional and continuous object. A simple example is the circle. In everyday use of the term "curve", a straight line is not curved, but in mathematical parlance curves include straight lines and line segments. A large number of other curves have been studied in geometry.

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:25, topic:198221”][quote author=qauters link=topic=262873.msg2180884#msg2180884 date=1208009008]

as for curveArrayX/Y …anyone want to tell him?
[/quote]i have never bothered to look what people mean by these, i have just assumed them to be the precalculated sine/cosine arrays

Think before you write! They aren’t array’s, so they can’t be the precalculated sine/cosine array’s can they?

            X -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosX();
            tileCalculation -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosZ();
            int curvexsin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvexcos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
            Y -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosY();
            int curveysin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];
            int curveycos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];

As you see in this code example, you can guess why it’s called curveX and curveY.
They aren’t named to good, but if you see it in code, you can understand it.

they were talking about

as for curveArrayX/Y …anyone want to tell him?

array =], therefore frank_ is actually right.[/quote]
Thought of that first, but since no one posted an output with curveArray’s. I didn’t completly understand his sentence.

Could some one explain difference between an angle and a curve, cause I’m used to Dutch math, so I don’t understand the namings.

Edit: I only looked at his first log, not his second. I’m sorry for my mistake.
I just noticed I hooked it myself aswell, but I don’t use it. I think it’s the sin/curve array, but as I hook the wrong things (same as speedster), I can’t be to sure.

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

agree, the word “curve” is annoyingly ambiguous and you can also get curves from quadratic and cubic equations, sin/cos are not the only way to get curves.

those arrays aren’t exactly caches of the Math.sin() Math.cos() things, the ones in the Math class use radians, so a full circle for them is 2*Pi, but for angles used in the client, a full circle is 2048 or something,

i was thinking of the names “sinCache” and “cosCache” perhaps?

am I the only person who thinks getCameraPitch() and getCameraYaw() is a good idea?

Read full topic

item.description:

as for curveArrayX/Y …anyone want to tell him?
[/quote]i have never bothered to look what people mean by these, i have just assumed them to be the precalculated sine/cosine arrays[/quote]
Think before you write! They aren’t array’s, so they can’t be the precalculated sine/cosine array’s can they?

            X -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosX();
            tileCalculation -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosZ();
            int curvexsin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvexcos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
            Y -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosY();
            int curveysin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];
            int curveycos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];

As you see in this code example, you can guess why it’s called curveX and curveY.
They aren’t named to good, but if you see it in code, you can understand it.

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:17, topic:198221”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=262873.msg2177771#msg2177771 date=1207882757]

[Executing transforms for Minimap] *getMinimapInt3() into class client returns FIELD int ge.qb *getMinimapInt2() into class client returns FIELD int ge.jb *getMinimapInt1() into class client returns STATIC int u.G
ya, i can see how you will use shit that you cannot even name
[/quote]

I find it funny that the internal architecture of the client has undergone a drastic change, and you haven’t even realized it, yet you still think you have the right to flame.[/quote]
I find it funny that you don’t know a shit about the internal architecture of the client. If you take a good old aryan deob, you can find nearly every method in it.
The highest changes are the methodCounter, more static methods, their own string class, better obfuscation. They rebuild the way interfaces work.
Also you can update Aryan to this new engine without much trouble, as long as you rebuild some structures and you don’t invoke methods directly.
(Unless you want to keep track of the counters). Although this would get you banned, it would be the same as it was at the old engine.

(This is speaking of the client 490! So if it changed drasticly after that, then I’m wrong XD)

Read full topic

also, get rid of cameraCurveX/Y, where is the curve anyway? call them cameraPitch and cameraYaw

also, don’t use reflection to set fields, use bytecode and make a setter method,
its like making a getter method, only not,
okay play with reflection with fields for a bit, but my advice is move away from it as quickly as possible

as for curveArrayX/Y …anyone want to tell him?

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“speedster239, post:16, topic:198221”]minimapInt3 - The compass scale (the size of the loaded area relative to the users view of the minimap), using setInt in the reflection package I was able to zoom in or out on the loaded area with this field to produce a closer view of the map or a broader view.

minimapInt2 - The angle of the compass that the user sets, this is an integer from 0 to 2048, using setInt I also experimented with automatically setting the compass angle and have applied this field to write a setCompass(int angle) method in my bot.

minimapInt1 - The offset of the angle of the compass, i also messed around with this field in order to make sure that the user set angle always remains the same

All in all these three, as well as the player/base coordinates, are used to make the necessary calculations in order to walk using the minimap. But hey, I’m still new to the client and I know most of the people here know alot more than me but in good time I hope that I can help somebody else who is new…[/quote]
why dont you name them better, then?

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:17, topic:198221”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=262873.msg2177771#msg2177771 date=1207882757]

[Executing transforms for Minimap] *getMinimapInt3() into class client returns FIELD int ge.qb *getMinimapInt2() into class client returns FIELD int ge.jb *getMinimapInt1() into class client returns STATIC int u.G
ya, i can see how you will use shit that you cannot even name
[/quote]

I find it funny that the internal architecture of the client has undergone a drastic change, and you haven’t even realized it, yet you still think you have the right to flame.[/quote]i think you only say that because you are ignorant on how little it can actually change but still believe what psb says despite the fact that he is consistently wrong

also i havent even looked at a client for well over 8 months, so eat a dick, niggerlips

Read full topic

item.title: Client #492
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:15, topic:198221”][Executing transforms for Minimap] *getMinimapInt3() into class client returns FIELD int ge.qb *getMinimapInt2() into class client returns FIELD int ge.jb *getMinimapInt1() into class client returns STATIC int u.G
ya, i can see how you will use shit that you cannot even name[/quote]

minimapInt3 - The compass scale (the size of the loaded area relative to the users view of the minimap), using setInt in the reflection package I was able to zoom in or out on the loaded area with this field to produce a closer view of the map or a broader view.

minimapInt2 - The angle of the compass that the user sets, this is an integer from 0 to 2048, using setInt I also experimented with automatically setting the compass angle and have applied this field to write a setCompass(int angle) method in my bot.

minimapInt1 - The offset of the angle of the compass, i also messed around with this field in order to make sure that the user set angle always remains the same

All in all these three, as well as the player/base coordinates, are used to make the necessary calculations in order to walk using the minimap. But hey, I’m still new to the client and I know most of the people here know alot more than me but in good time I hope that I can help somebody else who is new…

As for client 493:

238 classes loaded in 514 ms.
